clinical_study.brief_title: A Technology-Enhanced Approach for Implementing Evidence-Based Practices in Child Welfare
clinical_study.official_title: A Technology-Enhanced Approach for Implementing Evidence-Based Practices in Child Welfare

brief_summary.textblock: In this study, a computer-assisted adaptation of SafeCare, an evidence-based home visiting program, will be developed and tested in child welfare. This approach will assist home visitors with delivery of SafeCare to families, with the goal of improving provider fidelity and implementation success. In the computer-assisted SafeCare sessions, a portion of the session will be delivered on a tablet computer that the home visitor brings to the family's home. The computer software will deliver the educational piece, or explain piece of each session, along with modeling videos of the skills. The home visitor will follow up with the practice and feedback portions of the session. A randomized feasibility trial will be conducted to test the technology-based approach against the standard SafeCare implementation approach in terms of feasibility of implementation, provider job demands and resources, as well as client outcomes such as skill acquisition and mental health.

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility of Technology-Assisted SafeCare as measured by provider satisfaction surveys and qualitative interviews
primary_outcome.time_frame: Approximately six months after completing the baseline assessment
primary_outcome.description: The investigators will examine provider acceptability and feasibility of Technology-Assisted SafeCare by averaging provider satisfaction measures to impart an overall satisfaction score for this implementation approach, as well as summarizing qualitative data collected at the Tech-Assisted SafeCare providers' exit interview (approximately six months after the baseline assessment). Providers will rate items on the satisfaction survey on a scale from one to five.

primary_outcome.measure: Job demands and resources as measured by the Job Content Questionnaire and questions developed by the investigators - baseline measurement
primary_outcome.description: The investigators will examine the effect of implementation condition on participant-reported job demands and resources. Job demands and resources will be measured using the Job Content Questionnaire (Karasek et al., 1998), specifically the skill discretion, decision authority, psychological demands, depression, and satisfaction scales. Participants will also be asked several questions developed by the investigators regarding the number of families they serve at a given time (i.e. caseload) and number of times they contact those families per week. Participants will respond to these questions in an online survey completed at baseline.

primary_outcome.measure: Job demands and resources as measured by the Job Content Questionnaire and questions developed by the investigators - 3-month follow-up measurement
primary_outcome.time_frame: Approximately three months following the baseline assessment
primary_outcome.description: The investigators will examine the effect of implementation condition on participant-reported job demands and resources. Job demands and resources will be measured using the Job Content Questionnaire (Karasek et al., 1998), specifically the skill discretion, decision authority, psychological demands, depression, and satisfaction scales. Participants will also be asked several questions developed by the investigators regarding the number of families they serve at a given time (i.e. caseload) and number of times they contact those families per week. Participants will respond to these questions in an online survey completed approximately three months after the baseline assessment.

primary_outcome.measure: Job demands and resources as measured by the Job Content Questionnaire and questions developed by the investigators - 6-month follow-up measurement
primary_outcome.time_frame: Approximately six months following the baseline assessment
primary_outcome.description: The investigators will examine the effect of implementation condition on participant-reported job demands and resources. Job demands and resources will be measured using the Job Content Questionnaire (Karasek et al., 1998), specifically the skill discretion, decision authority, psychological demands, depression, and satisfaction scales. Participants will also be asked several questions developed by the investigators regarding the number of families they serve at a given time (i.e. caseload) and number of times they contact those families per week. Participants will respond to these questions in an online survey completed approximately six months after the baseline assessment.

primary_outcome.measure: Fidelity as measured by the SafeCare fidelity checklist
primary_outcome.time_frame: Data collected throughout the six months of the study - Measured for nine sessions until home visitor certification is reached and once per month thereafter (per intervention protocol)
primary_outcome.description: Each participant's fidelity to the model will be measured using the SafeCare fidelity checklist. Per standard SafeCare protocol, all SafeCare home visitors are fidelity monitored by a coach in order to assess their adherence to the model. They receive fidelity monitoring for nine sessions (three in each of three modules) until they reach certification and once per month thereafter. All fidelity scores for the participants will be collected from baseline assessment to six-month follow-up in order to assess the effect of implementation condition on fidelity scores. The frequency of fidelity assessment will vary depending on the caseload of each home visitor participant.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Approximately six months after the baseline assessment
primary_outcome.description: The investigators will document which phase of implementation (workshop completion, certification, or fidelity maintenance) each participant has reached at the time of the six-month follow-up assessment.

primary_outcome.measure: Time spent on SafeCare session preparation, completion, and follow-up as documented on a time diary form
primary_outcome.time_frame: Following each SafeCare session conducted during the six months of the study
primary_outcome.description: The time spent on SafeCare session preparation, completion, and follow-up will be documented using a time diary form developed by the investigators. This form is used to document the time home visitors spend on job-related activities such as preparing for home visits, conducting home visits, and completing notes, among other activities. All participants will complete the form following each SafeCare session they complete during the six months of the study. The total number of time diaries completed will vary depending on the home visitor's caseload.

secondary_outcome.measure: Parent child abuse potential as measured by the Brief Child Abuse Potential Inventory - Baseline Measurement
secondary_outcome.description: Parent child abuse potential will be assessed during the baseline assessment using the Brief Child Abuse Potential Inventory (Ondersma, Chaffin, Simpson, & LeBreton, 2003). This measure is a shorter version of the 160-item Child Abuse Potential Inventory (CAPI) (Milner, 1986), making it less time consuming and, thus, easier to administer while retaining good reliability and validity. The 34-item BCAP consists of a series of Agree/Disagree statements. These data will be collected by a research assessor in a phone interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in parent child abuse potential as measured by the Brief Child Abuse Potential Inventory at approximately 18 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Parent child abuse potential will be assessed again approximately 18 weeks after the baseline assessment using the Brief Child Abuse Potential Inventory (Ondersma, Chaffin, Simpson, & LeBreton, 2003) to assess change from baseline. This measure is a shorter version of the 160-item Child Abuse Potential Inventory (CAPI) (Milner, 1986), making it less time consuming and, thus, easier to administer while retaining good reliability and validity. The 34-item BCAP consists of a series of Agree/Disagree statements. These data will be collected by a research assessor in a phone interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Child internalizing and externalizing problems as measured by the Child Behavior Checklist - Baseline measurement
secondary_outcome.description: Child internalizing and externalizing problems will be assessed during the baseline assessment using the Child Behavior Checklist, or CBCL (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2000). The CBCL is a 99-item instrument that asks parents to rate how often certain behaviors have been true of their child in the past two months, from not true to very true/often true. The measure consists of seven scales: emotionally reactive, anxious/depressed, somatic complaints, withdrawn, attention problems, aggressive behavior, and sleep problems. These data will be collected by a research assessor in a phone interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in child internalizing and externalizing problems as measured by the Child Behavior Checklist at approximately 18 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Child internalizing and externalizing problems will be assessed again approximately 18 weeks the baseline assessment using the Child Behavior Checklist, or CBCL (Achenbach & Rescorla, 2000) to assess change from baseline. The CBCL is a 99-item instrument that asks parents to rate how often certain behaviors have been true of their child in the past two months, from not true to very true/often true. The measure consists of seven scales: emotionally reactive, anxious/depressed, somatic complaints, withdrawn, attention problems, aggressive behavior, and sleep problems. These data will be collected by a research assessor in a phone interview.

secondary_outcome.measure: Parental use of SafeCare parent-child interaction skills as measured by standard SafeCare assessment (Child Planned Activities Training Checklist) - baseline measurement
secondary_outcome.description: The investigators will obtain documentation of the parent participant's use of parent-child interaction skills from the home visitor's formal assessment as part of standard SafeCare delivery. This is measured using the SafeCare Child Planned Activities Training Checklist. Using this checklist, the home visitor assesses the parent's use of 10 parenting behaviors during routine activities.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in parental use of SafeCare parent-child interaction skills as measured by standard SafeCare assessment (Child Planned Activities Training Checklist) at six weeks post baseline
secondary_outcome.description: To assess change in parental use of parent-child interaction skills from baseline, the investigators will obtain the SafeCare Child Planned Activities Training Checklist from the home visitor's formal assessment approximately six weeks following baseline, as part of standard SafeCare delivery. Using this checklist, the home visitor assesses the parent's use of 10 parenting behaviors during routine activities.

secondary_outcome.measure: Parental use of SafeCare safety skills as measured by standard SafeCare assessment (Home Accident Prevention Inventory) - baseline measurement
secondary_outcome.description: The investigators will obtain documentation of the parent participant's use of home safety skills from the home visitor's formal assessment as part of standard SafeCare delivery. This is measured using the SafeCare Home Accident Prevention Inventory. Using this inventory, the home visitor assesses safety hazards in three rooms of the parent's home.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in parental use of SafeCare safety skills as measured by standard SafeCare assessment (Home Accident Prevention Inventory) at six weeks post baseline
secondary_outcome.description: To assess change in parental use of home safety skills from baseline, the investigators will obtain the SafeCare Home Accident Prevention Inventory from the home visitor's formal assessment approximately six weeks following baseline. Using this inventory, the home visitor assesses safety hazards in three rooms of the parent's home.

secondary_outcome.measure: Parental knowledge of SafeCare health skills as measured by standard SafeCare assessment (Sick or Injured Child Checklist) - baseline measurement
secondary_outcome.description: The investigators will obtain documentation of the parent participant's knowledge of child health skills from the home visitor formal assessment as part of standard SafeCare delivery. This is measured using the SafeCare Sick or Injured Child Checklist. Using this checklist, the home visitor assesses the parent's ability to identify illnesses and delivery appropriate treatment.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in parental knowledge of SafeCare health skills as measured by standard SafeCare assessment (Sick or Injured Child Checklist) at six weeks post baseline
secondary_outcome.description: To assess change in parental knowledge of child health skills from baseline, the investigators will obtain the SafeCare Sick or Injured Child Checklist from the home visitor's formal assessment approximately six weeks following baseline, as part of standard SafeCare delivery. Using this checklist, the home visitor assesses the parent's ability to identify illnesses and delivery appropriate treatment.

Parent satisfaction with the program will be assessed using the standard SafeCare satisfaction survey. The survey will be completed by the parent and will contain a series of statements about the program that the parent is asked to rate on a scale of one to five.

arm_group.description: A modified version of SafeCare, using a tablet and online program to complete a portion of the session
SafeCare as it is usually delivered

intervention.description: SafeCare, an evidence-based home visiting program

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Home Visitors: Home Visitors who are being trained in SafeCare
- Parents: English-speaking SafeCare parents with a child between the ages of 1.5-5 years who are receiving services from a Home Visitor who is in this study
Exclusion Criteria:
- Home Visitors: Home Visitors not being trained in SafeCare; Home Visitors who exclusively serve Spanish-speaking families
- Parents: Parents not receiving SafeCare; parents whose Home Visitor is not a participant in this study; parents under age 18 or who have a child outside of the ages of 1.5-5 years

facility.name: Georgia State University, School of Public Health, National SafeCare Training & Research Center

results_reference.citation: Cowart-Osborne M, Jackson M, Chege E, Baker E, Whitaker D, Self-Brown S. Technology-Based Innovations in Child Maltreatment Prevention Programs: Examples from SafeCare®. Soc Sci (Basel). 2014 Aug 15;3(3):427-440.
